Dialogue.Stage Direction: A small, cluttered room, illuminated by the flickering light of a single oil lamp. Scrolls are piled high on shelves and scattered across a large wooden desk. CLAUDIUS (40s, scholarly, with a slight stammer), paces back and forth, his brow furrowed in thought.
belches

Dialogue.Line: Shouldn't eat so much at night. Mushrooms. Yes. I'm working too hard. Yes. Too much work. I must get it all done though. I must finish. Now, where was I? Augustus died, yes. Uncle Tiberius took his place. But he didn't want it. Not then. Waited too long. Yes. Strange man. Filthy brute. All power corrupts. Only one man kept him in check - Germanicus, my brother. My dear brother Germanicus. Tiberius sent him to Syria to take command and then...

metadata.title: Ominous Reflections in a Lamp-Lit Study
metadata.description: In the hushed solitude of his study, Claudius is surrounded by towering stacks of scrolls, their ancient wisdom casting long shadows in the flickering lamplight. The air is thick with the scent of old parchment and the quiet weight of history. Claudius, burdened by a recent heavy meal and the even heavier weight of imperial affairs, paces thoughtfully. His soliloquy begins with a physical discomfort, a belch that breaks the silence, before his mind drifts to the tumultuous events that have shaped Rome. He reflects on the death of Augustus and the ascension of his uncle Tiberius, painting a grim portrait of the new emperor as a reluctant and corrupted ruler. The scene's atmosphere is one of introspection and foreboding, as Claudius sets the stage for the unfolding drama by hinting at the pivotal role of his beloved brother, Germanicus, and the shadows gathering around Tiberius's reign. This scene serves as a narrative prologue, establishing Claudius as our insightful, if somewhat physically preoccupied, guide through the treacherous landscape of Roman power, and foreshadowing the conflicts to come.

events.title: Claudius Recounts Imperial Succession and Tiberius's Uneasy Reign
events.description: Claudius, in his study amidst piles of scrolls, breaks the silence with a burp, humorously blaming a late-night mushroom supper. He then shifts to a somber reflection on the recent history of Rome, specifically the death of Augustus and the reluctant rise of Tiberius to emperor. Claudius describes Tiberius as a "strange man" and a "filthy brute," suggesting a critical and perhaps fearful perspective on his uncle's rule. He notes Tiberius's initial hesitation to take power and implies a sense of corruption stemming from absolute authority. This event is crucial for exposition, establishing the political backdrop of the narrative and setting a tone of unease and moral decay within the Roman Empire. It introduces Claudius's role as a historian and commentator, offering his personal, often wry, observations on the unfolding imperial drama.
key_dialogue: CLAUDIUS: Shouldn't eat so much at night. Mushrooms. Yes.
CLAUDIUS: Yes. I'm working too hard. Yes. Too much work. I must get it all done though. I must finish.
CLAUDIUS: Augustus died, yes. Uncle Tiberius took his place. But he didn't want it. Not then. Waited too long. Yes. Strange man. Filthy brute. All power corrupts.
CLAUDIUS: Only one man kept him in check - Germanicus, my brother. My dear brother Germanicus.

agent_participations.current_status: Claudius paces back and forth in his cluttered study, surrounded by piles of scrolls. His posture is slightly hunched, betraying the weight of his thoughts. He gestures animatedly as he speaks, punctuating his reflections with a belch that briefly interrupts his serious demeanor.
agent_participations.emotional_state: Outwardly, Claudius presents a facade of humor with his self-deprecating remarks about the mushrooms, masking his deeper feelings of unease and tension regarding the events he recounts. Internally, he grapples with fear and a profound sense of loss for Germanicus, his brother, and wrestles with the implications of Tiberius's rule. His emotions are a tumultuous blend of anxiety and resignation, indicative of a man caught in the web of political turmoil.
active_plans: To document the succession of power in the Roman Empire, emphasizing the flaws of Tiberius's character.
To reflect on the implications of his family's history and the moral decay surrounding imperial authority.
To maintain a sense of humor in his observations, using it as a coping mechanism amidst the grim realities of the court.
beliefs: Corruption is an inherent trait of those who hold absolute power.
The truth of history must be preserved, even if it casts dark shadows on his family.
Humor can be a shield against the pain of loss and the chaos of the world around him.
goals: Short-term: To finish recounting recent events in Roman history for his personal understanding.
Medium-term: To create a comprehensive narrative that highlights the dangers of unchecked ambition.
Ultimate: To emerge as a voice of reason and witness in a tumultuous imperial landscape, potentially influencing future generations.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A bustling marketplace in Antioch, alive with the clamor of mourning citizens. The hearse carrying GERMANICUS’s ashes becomes a focal point of collective sorrow and political statement. The air is thick with lamentations and public dissent. A large crowd of TOWNSFOLK is gathered, their faces etched with grief.
AGRIPPINA, a noblewoman, stands beside the hearse, her face contorted in anguish.

Dialogue.Line: Let his body be laid in the marketplace at Antioch so that the people may see the marks of poison and witchery on his body. Let word be sent to Rome. Germanicus is dead. Germanicus is dead. Oh, nothing now stands between Rome and her Imperial destiny.  She gestures dramatically towards the urn containing Germanicus's ashes. Mournful trumpeting sounds.
Thus, my children... does your father come home to you. Ashes in an urn. Look at him! Remember him! Remember all your days how your father returned to you.  The crowd murmurs in response.

Take it, CASTOR! Carry it to Rome. And by the love you had for my dear husband, defend his children and avenge his death! My babies! My babies! What have they done to you? And CLAUDIUS, dear Claudius you, I know, loved him.  CLAUDIUS (40s, scholarly, with a slight stammer), stands nearby, looking genuinely distraught.
He was dearer to me than anyone. Nobody had such a brother.
Where is the Emperor? And where is LIVIA?  HEROD steps forward.
Too stricken with grief to appear in public.
And your mother?
The same.

Oh, is their grief greater than ours, then? All along the way, in every town and village, the people flooded to pay their respect to his ashes as we passed. The air was filled with cries and lamentations. Look at the faces of these people here. It's as if they've lost a son or a father of their own. Yet the man he called father and the woman who was his grandmother do not come out to greet us! I ask again, is their grief greater than ours?  The crowd roars in response.
No! No!
Put the ashes on the hearse and let us journey on to Rome.

metadata.title: Agrippina's Lament and Call to Arms
metadata.description: Set against the backdrop of the bustling Antioch Marketplace, this scene pulsates with the collective grief of mourning citizens. The hearse carrying Germanicus's ashes stands central, surrounded by townsfolk whose expressions reflect a mixture of deep sorrow and simmering indignation. Agrippina, a noblewoman clad in black, radiates both anguish and fierce determination as she stands beside the hearse, her face contorted in grief but her voice rising with a commanding presence. The air is thick with lamentations and the mournful sound of trumpets, amplifying the emotional atmosphere that seethes with a tension between public mourning and political unrest. As Agrippina passionately speaks of her late husband, she transforms his death into a rallying cry for justice, challenging the absence of Tiberius and Livia. This moment serves as a catalyst, igniting public dissent and solidifying Agrippina's role as a figurehead of resistance against imperial authority. The scene underscores the themes of justice, family, and the fragile nature of loyalty amidst the chaos of Roman power, as it sets the stage for the impending political upheaval.

events.title: Agrippina Demands Justice
events.description: Agrippina stands beside the hearse carrying Germanicus's ashes, her anguish palpable as she implores the townsfolk to witness the marks of poison on his body, asserting his death was not by misfortune but by treachery. In her impassioned speech, she calls for the people to remember Germanicus and to avenge his death. Her words resonate through the crowd, unifying their grief into a potent demand for justice against the imperial powers. The emotional weight of her message stirs the townsfolk, who respond with vigorous agreement, reflecting the brewing animosity toward the imperial regime. This event marks a significant turning point, thrusting Agrippina into the role of a political leader and galvanizing the masses against Tiberius’s authority.
key_dialogue: Let his body be laid in the marketplace at Antioch so that the people may see the marks of poison and witchery on his body.
Thus, my children... does your father come home to you. Ashes in an urn. Look at him! Remember him!
Take it, CASTOR! Carry it to Rome. And by the love you had for my dear husband, defend his children and avenge his death!

events.title: The Crowd's Response
events.description: As Agrippina's impassioned words echo through the marketplace, the crowd reacts fervently, their collective grief morphing into a unified roar of dissent against the imperial family. Agrippina's questioning of Tiberius and Livia's absence ignites a fierce emotional response, with the townspeople expressing their outrage at the perceived neglect from their leaders. This shared sentiment transforms the mourning into a powerful political statement, emphasizing the connection between Germanicus’s death and the growing discontent with the empire's ruling class. The scene crescendos with the crowd's chanting, further solidifying Agrippina's position as a leader of the people's movement.
key_dialogue: Oh, is their grief greater than ours, then? [...] Look at the faces of these people here. It's as if they've lost a son or a father of their own. Yet the man he called father and the woman who was his grandmother do not come out to greet us!
No! No!

agent_participations.current_status: Agrippina stands tall and resolute beside the hearse carrying her husband's ashes, a figure of raw grief transformed into commanding presence. She gestures emphatically towards the urn, her voice ringing out across the marketplace. Her movements are sharp and deliberate, each gesture designed to amplify her message of injustice and loss, ensuring every townsfolk witnesses her profound sorrow and righteous anger.
agent_participations.emotional_state: On the surface, Agrippina is a whirlwind of anguish and fury. Her voice cracks with grief as she speaks of her husband, yet beneath this raw pain lies a steely resolve. Her sorrow is not just personal; it's a calculated performance of public mourning, strategically deployed to incite outrage. She is torn between genuine heartbreak and a burning desire for vengeance, using her emotional display as a potent weapon against her political enemies, masking her calculated strategy beneath a veneer of passionate grief.
active_plans: To publicly display Germanicus's ashes and emphasize the signs of poisoning to galvanize public opinion against Tiberius.
To directly challenge the Emperor and Livia's absence, implying their indifference to Germanicus's death and inciting further public resentment.
To dispatch Castor to Rome with the ashes, transforming him into a messenger of her grief and a living symbol of her demand for justice within the heart of the empire.
beliefs: Germanicus was not only murdered but also a victim of foul play and dark magic, demanding retribution.
The Roman people are inherently just and will rally to support a righteous cause when presented with clear evidence of injustice.
Tiberius and Livia are either directly complicit in Germanicus's death or indifferent to the suffering of his family, deserving of public condemnation.
goals: short-term": "To ignite immediate and widespread outrage in Antioch against the perceived perpetrators of Germanicus's death.
medium-term": "To pressure Tiberius into launching a formal investigation into Germanicus's death, ensuring public accountability and justice.
ultimate": "To avenge Germanicus's murder, secure the safety and future of her children, and dismantle the power structures she believes are responsible for his demise.

agent_participations.current_status: Castor stands attentively near Agrippina and Claudius, his posture reflecting a dutiful readiness. When Agrippina directs him, he steps forward to receive the urn containing Germanicus's ashes. His movements are respectful and solemn as he accepts this heavy symbolic burden, physically embodying the weight of Agrippina's demands and the gravity of the moment.
agent_participations.emotional_state: Castor displays a somber and respectful demeanor, indicative of mourning for Germanicus. Internally, he is likely navigating a complex web of loyalties. While he shows deference to Agrippina's grief and agrees to her request, he remains Tiberius's son, potentially creating an internal conflict. He is caught between familial duty to the imperial house and the emotional weight of Agrippina's passionate appeal, his true feelings masked by a veneer of controlled solemnity.
active_plans: To accept and carefully handle Germanicus's ashes, demonstrating respect for the deceased and compliance with Agrippina's wishes.
To transport the urn to Rome as instructed, acting as Agrippina's agent in delivering her message to the imperial capital.
To 'defend Germanicus's children and avenge his death' as charged by Agrippina, although the specifics of these actions remain undefined and open to interpretation based on his own loyalties.
beliefs: Honoring the dead, especially someone of Germanicus's stature, is a fundamental Roman duty.
Maintaining order and fulfilling familial obligations are crucial for personal and societal stability, even amidst emotional turmoil.
Justice, while important, must be pursued within the boundaries of Roman law and imperial authority, potentially conflicting with Agrippina's more emotionally driven demands.
goals: short-term": "To respectfully receive and secure Germanicus's ashes in the Antioch marketplace.
medium-term": "To safely transport the ashes to Rome and deliver them as directed, fulfilling Agrippina's immediate request.

ultimate": "To navigate the complex political fallout from Germanicus's death while upholding his duty to both his family and the Roman state, seeking a path that balances justice with imperial stability (as defined by Tiberius).

agent_participations.current_status: Claudius stands nearby, his posture suggesting a mix of genuine distress and cautious observation. He listens intently to Agrippina's impassioned speech, his expression reflecting deep sorrow. When addressed directly, he steps forward slightly, his stutter momentarily more pronounced as he expresses his grief for Germanicus, remaining physically present but somewhat removed from the immediate emotional storm surrounding Agrippina.
agent_participations.emotional_state: Claudius is genuinely distraught by Germanicus's death, his words conveying sincere affection and loss. However, his outward display is tempered by his inherent caution. He is emotionally affected by Agrippina's grief, yet also acutely aware of the political implications of her public display. Internally, he is likely experiencing a conflict between his personal sorrow and his ingrained need for self-preservation within the dangerous imperial court, observing the unfolding drama with a scholar's detached yet empathetic eye.
active_plans: To offer verbal condolences and express his genuine grief for Germanicus, fulfilling social expectations and his personal feelings.
To observe Agrippina's actions and the crowd's reaction, gathering information and assessing the political ramifications of this public display of mourning.

To maintain a position of relative neutrality, avoiding direct endorsement or opposition to Agrippina's accusations, seeking to remain an observer rather than a participant in the escalating conflict.
beliefs: Germanicus was a truly exceptional man, whose loss is a profound tragedy for Rome and for him personally.
The imperial court is a dangerous and manipulative environment where overt displays of emotion can be politically risky.
Careful observation and intellectual understanding are essential tools for navigating the treacherous currents of Roman politics, offering a form of passive agency.
goals: short-term": "To express his personal grief and offer support to Agrippina in a socially acceptable manner.
medium-term": "To understand the full extent of the political fallout from Germanicus's death and Agrippina's actions, assessing potential threats and opportunities.

ultimate": "To survive the political turmoil within the Julio-Claudian dynasty, continuing his role as an observer and chronicler, perhaps one day to make sense of the chaos he witnesses, while protecting himself from direct involvement in dangerous power struggles.

agent_participations.current_status: Herod steps forward with a measured and diplomatic demeanor to address Agrippina's pointed questions. He speaks calmly and authoritatively, acting as a representative of the absent imperial family. His posture is controlled, his gestures minimal, conveying an air of pragmatic composure amidst the emotional intensity of the marketplace. He positions himself as a voice of reason and imperial explanation.
agent_participations.emotional_state: Herod presents a façade of calm detachment and political pragmatism. He shows no outward emotion, maintaining a neutral and informative tone. Internally, he is likely assessing the volatile situation and the potential for public unrest incited by Agrippina. While outwardly placid, he is undoubtedly aware of the dangerous undercurrents and the political implications of the imperial family's absence, prioritizing damage control and maintaining imperial authority through controlled communication.
active_plans: To provide a plausible explanation for Tiberius and Livia's absence, deflecting Agrippina's direct challenge and attempting to soothe public discontent.
To minimize the political damage caused by Agrippina's public accusations and prevent further escalation of public outrage against the imperial regime.
To observe and assess the crowd's reaction to Agrippina's speech and his own explanations, gauging the level of public dissent and reporting back to the imperial court.
beliefs: Maintaining imperial decorum and public order is paramount, especially in times of grief and potential unrest.
Direct confrontation with Agrippina in her highly emotional state would be unproductive and could further inflame public sentiment.
A calm and reasoned approach, emphasizing the imperial family's grief (however genuine or not), is the most effective way to manage the immediate crisis in Antioch.
goals: short-term": "To quell Agrippina's immediate challenge and prevent the crowd's emotional response from escalating into open revolt or disorder in Antioch.
medium-term": "To reassure the public of the imperial family's concern (or at least project that image) and contain the political fallout from Germanicus's death.
ultimate": "To maintain stability within the Roman Empire and protect the interests of the imperial regime, ensuring his own continued favor and influence within the political landscape.

agent_participations.current_status: Agrippina stands resolutely beside the hearse, her posture commanding as she gestures dramatically towards the urn containing Germanicus's ashes. Her body emanates a mix of anguish and fierce determination, her movements sharp and deliberate as she engages the crowd, her face a canvas of grief and righteous fury.
agent_participations.emotional_state: Outwardly, Agrippina displays intense anguish, tears glistening in her eyes as she speaks passionately, her voice trembling with emotion. Internally, she wrestles with a storm of grief and fiery indignation, feeling the weight of her husband's death as a personal affront to her family. Her motivations are driven by both sorrow and a fierce desire for justice for Germanicus, intensifying her resolve to challenge the imperial family.
active_plans: Galvanize the crowd to rally against Tiberius and Livia's perceived neglect.
Transform public mourning into a powerful political statement.
Incite the townspeople to carry Germanicus's ashes to Rome as a symbol of justice and rebellion.
beliefs: Justice must be served for Germanicus's death, and the people deserve to know the truth.
Her husband's legacy is worth fighting for, and she will not allow his memory to fade.
The imperial family's grief is superficial compared to the anguish of the people.
goals: Short-term: Rally the citizens to express their grief and dissent publicly.
Medium-term: Ensure Germanicus's ashes are taken to Rome as a symbol of justice.
Ultimate: Overthrow the indifference of the imperial regime and seek vengeance for her husband.

agent_participations.current_status: Claudius stands nearby, visibly distressed, his body tense as he watches Agrippina speak. His facial expressions reveal a mix of sorrow and admiration as he listens intently, his hands clenched at his sides, embodying the scholar caught in a political storm.
agent_participations.emotional_state: On the surface, Claudius appears mournful, his brow furrowed in concern and his voice shaky as he praises Germanicus. Internally, he grapples with feelings of helplessness and a deep desire to support Agrippina, while fearing the repercussions of openly opposing Tiberius. His love for Germanicus and loyalty to Agrippina create a complex web of emotions, leaving him torn between personal grief and political engagement.
active_plans: Support Agrippina in her quest for justice by publicly acknowledging Germanicus's significance.
Navigate the tension of familial loyalty while considering the possible repercussions from Tiberius.
Maintain a position of observation while contemplating how he can leverage his influence for Agrippina's cause.
beliefs: Germanicus's death was unjust, and the truth must be revealed to the people.
Silence in the face of tyranny is complicity, and he must act to prevent that.
His familial ties to the imperial family complicate his desire for justice and truth.
goals: Short-term: Express his sorrow and support for Agrippina's cause in the marketplace.
Medium-term: Find a way to protect Agrippina and her children amidst the brewing dissent.
Ultimate: Ensure that the truth about Germanicus's death is revealed, and contribute to a shift in power dynamics in Rome.

object_involvements.description_of_involvement: Germanicus's ashes, contained within a funerary urn, are the central object of this poignant scene. Agrippina dramatically gestures towards the urn, urging the townsfolk to 'look at him!' and 'see the marks of poison and witchery'. The ashes are not merely the physical remains of Germanicus; they are transformed into a potent symbol of injustice and imperial treachery. Agrippina uses them to visually and emotionally demonstrate her loss and to accuse unseen enemies of murder. The urn becomes a focal point for public grief and a rallying cry for vengeance, embodying Germanicus's martyrdom and fueling the growing discontent against Tiberius and Livia. Agrippina entrusts the urn to Castor, directing him to carry this symbol of loss and injustice to Rome, extending its impact far beyond Antioch.
object_involvements.object_status_before_event: Germanicus's ashes are being transported on the hearse, en route to Rome after his death in Antioch. They are moving through various towns and villages, becoming a focal point for mourning processions.
object_involvements.object_status_after_event: The ashes, still within the urn, have been publicly displayed in the Antioch marketplace, becoming a powerful catalyst for Agrippina's political speech and the crowd's emotional response. They are now entrusted to Castor to be transported to Rome, transforming them into a physical embodiment of Agrippina's demands for justice to be delivered directly to the heart of the empire.

object_involvements.description_of_involvement: The hearse serves as a mobile stage and a solemn platform within the bustling Antioch marketplace. It carries Germanicus's ashes, elevating them physically and symbolically above the crowd, making them visible to all and creating a focal point for mourning and political demonstration. Agrippina stands beside it, using it as a backdrop for her impassioned speech, further amplifying her presence and message. The hearse is not just a mode of transport; it becomes an integral part of the spectacle of public mourning and Agrippina's challenge to imperial authority, transforming a funerary vehicle into a symbol of political dissent and a catalyst for public action, drawing attention and lending gravitas to the unfolding drama.
object_involvements.object_status_before_event: The hearse is transporting Germanicus's ashes through Antioch, moving through the streets towards the marketplace, part of a larger procession of mourning.
object_involvements.object_status_after_event: The hearse is positioned prominently in the Antioch marketplace, having served its purpose as a platform for public mourning and Agrippina's speech. It remains ready to continue its journey to Rome, now carrying not just ashes but also the weight of public sentiment and Agrippina's explicit demands for justice, having become a symbol of both grief and rebellion.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: TIBERIUS (60s, Emperor of Rome, weary and suspicious), stands with SEJANUS (40s, ambitious and cunning Praetorian Prefect) and LIVIA (80s, powerful and manipulative Empress Dowager). Torches cast long shadows across their faces.

Dialogue.Line: A hundred thousand people out there. Mars Field is ablaze with torches.
The funeral will be over soon. The crowds will disperse.
Why did they admire him so?
When you're not the Emperor, you've always got the Emperor to blame.
My husband was Emperor for 40 years and he was admired by everyone.
Ah, well, I wasn't referring to gods.
When Augustus died, the troops on the Rhine would have made Germanicus Emperor, if he'd agreed to it.
Germanicus didn't believe in emperors. He'd done better if he had.
There's a lot of bad feeling out there and it's all directed at me! What do they want of me? They always preferred him to me. Why?
You just don't have a lovable nature. It's unfortunate but even your own son doesn't care for you much.
I think I'm loved by a great many people.
Well, you're loved alright, but you're not well loved.
And you are, I suppose?
Well, as to that I couldn't say but unlike you, I don't worry about it.
Well, at any rate, if he's profoundly loved, he's also profoundly dead. There's no harm in loving the dead. Everybody's loved when he's dead.
I wouldn't count on that, if I were you.
What is it you want, Mother?
I'm told that your son CASTOR and Agrippina intend to prosecute PISO and PLANCINA on charges of treason and murder.
They have no proof.
Well, I daresay, they could tell a pretty tale.
A pretty tale isn't proof.
That's a different story from the one you've been telling for the last five years. You've buried more men with your pretty tales than anyone I know.
Where is he now?
My last report said he'd taken ship from Illyria, he was on his way to Rome.
I won't have him tried.
Better to have him tried and cleared than to live forever under a cloud.
Well, it won't trouble Piso to live under a cloud.
I wasn't thinking of Piso. I was thinking of you.
Has it ever occurred to you, Mother, that it's you they hate and not me?
There is nothing in this world that occurs to you that has not occurred to me first. That is the affliction I live with.

metadata.title: Shadows of Popularity and Plots
metadata.description: Within the imposing Roman Palace, under the cloak of night, Emperor Tiberius grapples with the weight of his unpopularity in the wake of Germanicus's death. Torches flicker, casting elongated shadows that dance across the opulent yet cold stone walls, mirroring the unease and suspicion permeating the air. The emotional atmosphere is thick with political tension and familial discord as Tiberius, flanked by the ever-present Sejanus and the formidable Livia, voices his insecurities about the public's adoration for the deceased Germanicus. Livia, with her characteristic glacial demeanor and sharp intellect, subtly manipulates the conversation towards the impending trial of Piso and Plancina, revealing the power dynamics and undercurrents of ambition within the imperial family. This scene serves to highlight Tiberius's paranoia and Livia's manipulative control, setting the stage for the unfolding political drama and the perilous path ahead for the characters as they navigate the treacherous landscape of Roman power and public opinion in the aftermath of a national hero's demise.

events.title: Echoes of Public Grief and Imperial Insecurity
events.description: In the dimly lit Roman Palace, Tiberius, visibly disturbed by the outpouring of public grief for Germanicus, questions his own popularity. He notes the massive crowds gathered in Mars Field, their torches a symbol of their mourning and, implicitly, their preference for his deceased nephew. Sejanus attempts to placate Tiberius by dismissing public sentiment as mere scapegoating against the Emperor, while Livia subtly reminds Tiberius of Germanicus's past popularity and his own lack of public affection, emphasizing his 'unlovable nature'. This exchange immediately establishes Tiberius's deep-seated insecurity and the contrasting public image of Germanicus, setting the stage for the political tensions that will unfold.
key_dialogue: TIBERIUS: A hundred thousand people out there. Mars Field is ablaze with torches.
TIBERIUS: Why did they admire him so?
SEJANUS: When you're not the Emperor, you've always got the Emperor to blame.
LIVIA: My husband was Emperor for 40 years and he was admired by everyone.
LIVIA: You just don't have a lovable nature. It's unfortunate but even your own son doesn't care for you much.
TIBERIUS: I think I'm loved by a great many people.
LIVIA: Well, you're loved alright, but you're not well loved.
SEJANUS: Well, at any rate, if he's profoundly loved, he's also profoundly dead. There's no harm in loving the dead.

events.title: Livia Steers Towards Justice and Political Strategy
events.description: Livia, cutting through the emotional undercurrents of Tiberius's insecurity, abruptly shifts the focus to the impending legal proceedings against Piso and Plancina. She reveals her knowledge that Castor and Agrippina intend to prosecute them for treason and murder, directly confronting Tiberius with the political ramifications of Germanicus's death. Sejanus, ever the pragmatist, dismisses the threat, citing a lack of proof. However, Livia shrewdly counters, acknowledging the power of 'a pretty tale' in shaping public opinion and recalling Sejanus's own history of using fabricated narratives for political gain. This moment highlights Livia's strategic mind and her immediate grasp of the political chessboard, contrasting with Tiberius's more emotional and reactive approach.
key_dialogue: LIVIA: I'm told that your son CASTOR and Agrippina intend to prosecute PISO and PLANCINA on charges of treason and murder.
SEJANUS: They have no proof.
LIVIA: Well, I daresay, they could tell a pretty tale.
SEJANUS: A pretty tale isn't proof.
LIVIA: That's a different story from the one you've been telling for the last five years. You've buried more men with your pretty tales than anyone I know.

events.title: Imperial Resistance and Maternal Manipulation
events.description: Tiberius, initially resistant to the idea of Piso's trial, declares 'I won't have him tried', indicating his desire to control the situation and perhaps avoid further public scrutiny. Livia, however, skillfully reframes the issue, arguing that a trial, even if it clears Piso, would be beneficial for Tiberius by dispelling public suspicion. She subtly shifts the focus from Piso's fate to Tiberius's own image and political standing. When Tiberius petulantly suggests that the public's hatred is directed at Livia, not him, Livia delivers a cuttingly dismissive and superior retort, asserting her unparalleled understanding of political machinations and effectively silencing Tiberius. This final exchange underscores Livia's dominant position and her ability to manipulate Tiberius, reinforcing the power imbalance and setting the stage for her continued influence in the unfolding events.
key_dialogue: TIBERIUS: I won't have him tried.
LIVIA: Better to have him tried and cleared than to live forever under a cloud.
LIVIA: I wasn't thinking of Piso. I was thinking of you.
TIBERIUS: Has it ever occurred to you, Mother, that it's you they hate and not me?
LIVIA: There is nothing in this world that occurs to you that has not occurred to me first. That is the affliction I live with.

agent_participations.current_status: Tiberius stands in the dimly lit Roman Palace, his posture rigid with unease as he observes the distant glow of torches from Mars Field. He is visibly agitated, initiating the conversation with Sejanus and Livia, his words laced with a mixture of imperial command and personal insecurity. He gestures towards the unseen crowds, his movements betraying his inner turmoil.
agent_participations.emotional_state: Beneath a veneer of imperial detachment, Tiberius is deeply troubled by the outpouring of public affection for Germanicus. He outwardly questions the crowds' admiration, seeking validation and reassurance from his advisors. Internally, he is consumed by paranoia and jealousy, feeling overshadowed by his deceased nephew's popularity.  Unspoken is his fear of losing control and the gnawing insecurity about his own lovability and legitimacy as Emperor.
active_plans: Assess the true extent of public dissatisfaction and whether it poses a threat to his rule.
Seek reassurance from Sejanus and Livia to alleviate his anxieties about his popularity.
Understand why Germanicus was so admired by the people and identify what he lacks in comparison.
beliefs: Public opinion is a volatile and dangerous force that can quickly turn against a ruler.
Power is maintained through control and fear rather than affection or admiration.
He is inherently less charismatic and 'lovable' than his popular predecessor or relatives like Germanicus.
goals: Short-term: To quell his immediate anxiety and regain a sense of control over the situation.
Medium-term: To understand and manage the public sentiment, preventing it from escalating into open dissent.
Ultimate: To secure his position as Emperor and be respected, if not loved, by the Roman populace, despite feeling inherently unlovable.

agent_participations.current_status: Sejanus stands attentively beside Tiberius, his posture composed and reassuring. He listens carefully to the Emperor's anxieties, offering measured responses aimed at calming Tiberius's fears. He uses pragmatic language, downplaying the emotional significance of the public mourning and focusing on the practical aspects of crowd control and political management.
agent_participations.emotional_state: Sejanus presents a facade of calm professionalism and unwavering loyalty to Tiberius, his tone even and controlled. Internally, he is opportunistic, recognizing Tiberius's insecurity as a means to further solidify his own influence. He likely views the public grief with a degree of cynicism, dismissing it as fleeting and easily manipulated.  Unspoken is his ambition to capitalize on Tiberius's vulnerabilities and strengthen his position as the Emperor's indispensable advisor.
active_plans: Pacify Tiberius and reassure him that the public grief is not a direct threat to his authority.
Reinforce his image as a reliable and pragmatic advisor, essential to managing Tiberius's anxieties.
Observe Livia's interventions and gauge her influence in the situation to navigate the power dynamics effectively.
beliefs: Public displays of emotion are superficial and easily manipulated for political purposes.
An Emperor's strength lies in control and the projection of power, not in seeking popular affection.
His own cunning and strategic mind are superior to the emotional and insecure nature of rulers like Tiberius.
goals: Short-term: To de-escalate Tiberius's anxiety and maintain a calm atmosphere within the palace.
Medium-term: To strengthen his position as Tiberius's key advisor by appearing competent and in control.
Ultimate: To consolidate his power and influence within the Roman Empire, potentially even beyond his current role as Praetorian Prefect, by exploiting Tiberius's weaknesses.

agent_participations.current_status: Livia stands regally in the Roman Palace, her presence commanding and unwavering even amidst Tiberius's agitation. She listens to her son's concerns with a detached air, intervening with sharp, pointed remarks that cut through Sejanus's placating words. Her gaze is steady and penetrating, suggesting a deep understanding of the political currents at play.
agent_participations.emotional_state: Livia projects an aura of icy control and supreme confidence, her outward demeanor cool and almost dismissive of Tiberius's insecurities. Internally, she is deeply strategic and focused on the long-term stability of the Julio-Claudian dynasty. While she may hold some maternal concern for Tiberius, it is overshadowed by her overarching ambition to maintain power. Unspoken is her critical assessment of Tiberius's weaknesses and her determination to guide him – and the empire – according to her own vision.
active_plans: Subtly undermine Tiberius's self-confidence to reinforce her own position as the wiser, more capable leader.
Remind Tiberius of the political realities, including his lack of popular affection, to ensure he remains reliant on her counsel.
Steer the conversation towards matters of dynastic importance, such as the upcoming trial, to assert her influence over crucial decisions.
beliefs: The Julio-Claudian dynasty's survival is paramount and justifies ruthless actions if necessary.
Tiberius is fundamentally flawed as a ruler and requires her guidance to avoid disastrous mistakes.
Power is best wielded through manipulation and strategic foresight, not through emotional appeals or public affection.
goals: Short-term: To assert her dominance in the conversation and subtly control the narrative around Tiberius's insecurities.
Medium-term: To maintain her influence over Tiberius and ensure the dynasty's continued stability and power.
Ultimate: To secure the long-term legacy of the Julio-Claudian dynasty and her own place as its architect and protector, even if it requires manipulating her own son.

agent_participations.current_status: Livia stands poised and commanding, her posture radiating authority. She deftly navigates the conversation, her gestures precise, as she shifts the focus towards the impending trial of Piso and Plancina. Her voice cuts through the tension, drawing attention to the political ramifications with a sharpness that leaves little room for dissent.
agent_participations.emotional_state: Outwardly, Livia exudes confidence and control, her calm demeanor masking any hint of vulnerability. Internally, however, there is underlying tension as she navigates the precarious balance of power within her family and the empire. Her motivations are layered, revealing a fierce determination to protect her legacy while engaging in psychological sparring with Tiberius.
active_plans: To redirect Tiberius' focus from his insecurities to the pressing political issue of the trial against Piso and Plancina.
To reinforce her influence in the political landscape by reminding Tiberius of the potential consequences of Germanicus's death and the public's perception.
To subtly undermine Sejanus's confidence by recalling his own manipulation of narratives, thereby positioning herself as a more strategic player in the political game.
beliefs: The power of narrative and public perception can shape political outcomes.
Her family's legacy must be preserved at all costs, even if it requires manipulation or strategic sacrifice.
Tiberius's emotional weaknesses can be turned against him to maintain her own power.
goals: Short-term: To ensure Tiberius acknowledges the severity of the situation regarding Piso and Plancina.
Medium-term: To position herself as a key player in the coming trial, influencing its direction and outcome.
Ultimate: To secure her family's dominance in the imperial narrative and prevent any threats to their lineage.

agent_participations.current_status: Sejanus stands alongside Tiberius, maintaining a composed demeanor. His posture is relaxed yet alert, suggesting both confidence and readiness to respond. He interjects with calculated remarks, trying to mitigate Tiberius's concerns while subtly dismissing Livia's implications.
agent_participations.emotional_state: Sejanus displays a calm exterior, his confidence apparent as he counters Livia's assertions. Internally, he grapples with the tension of potential fallout from the trial, aware that any threat to Tiberius could also threaten his own position. His dismissive attitude toward the accusations reflects both his pragmatic approach and his desire to maintain control.
active_plans: To downplay the significance of the trial and reassure Tiberius that there is no substantial evidence against Piso and Plancina.
To position himself as a rational voice amidst the emotional turbulence of Tiberius and Livia's conversation.
To subtly reinforce Tiberius's authority by implying that public sentiment can be easily swayed, thus alleviating his insecurities.
beliefs: Power dynamics can be managed through careful control of information and perception.
The loyalty of the emperor is paramount, and it’s crucial to maintain Tiberius's confidence.
Manipulation and strategy are essential tools in navigating the treacherous landscape of Roman politics.
goals: Short-term: To reassure Tiberius that the trial poses no immediate threat to his authority.
Medium-term: To solidify his influence over Tiberius by presenting himself as the voice of reason.
Ultimate: To maneuver within the political landscape to secure his own position and influence while managing the consequences of others' actions.

agent_participations.current_status: Tiberius, weary from the weight of emperorship and the public mourning for Germanicus, stands amidst the grandeur of the Roman Palace. He paces slightly as he speaks, his posture conveying a mixture of imperial authority and deep unease. He directs questions to Sejanus and Livia, his gaze shifting between them as he seeks to understand the public mood and potential threats to his rule. He is physically present in the scene, but his mind seems preoccupied with the external pressures and perceived slights against him.
agent_participations.emotional_state: Tiberius is emotionally fraught, oscillating between insecurity and a fragile assertion of authority. Outwardly, he expresses weariness and suspicion, questioning the public's admiration for Germanicus and feeling personally attacked by their grief. Internally, he is deeply insecure and paranoid, convinced that the public prefers Germanicus and harbors resentment towards him. This insecurity fuels his defensiveness and petulance, particularly in his exchanges with Livia, revealing a profound lack of self-assurance beneath the emperor's facade.
active_plans: Assert his imperial authority by initially refusing Piso's trial, aiming to demonstrate control and prevent further agitation.
Seek reassurance from his advisors, particularly Livia and Sejanus, regarding his public image and the extent of the perceived threat.
Minimize public scrutiny and potential unrest by preventing the trial, hoping to quickly suppress the issue and return to a semblance of order.
beliefs: Public opinion is fickle and easily swayed, currently turned against him due to the outpouring of grief for Germanicus.
Maintaining absolute control is essential to his rule, and any event that could challenge his authority must be suppressed or managed meticulously.
He is inherently less 'lovable' than Germanicus, a perceived personal failing that fuels his insecurity and paranoia about his position.
goals: short-term": "Prevent Piso's trial to avoid exacerbating public unrest and maintain a semblance of control over the situation.
medium-term": "Improve his public image and quell the negative sentiment directed at him, attempting to regain public favor and dispel the shadow of Germanicus.
ultimate": "Secure his legacy as Emperor and solidify his reign, ensuring unchallenged authority and suppressing any threats to his power, real or imagined.

agent_participations.current_status: Livia stands with regal stillness in the Roman Palace, an imposing figure even in her advanced years. She listens intently to Tiberius and Sejanus, her posture radiating an unwavering confidence and control. When she speaks, her movements are minimal yet deliberate, each gesture underscoring the weight of her words and her dominant presence in the scene. She observes Tiberius with a critical, almost maternal gaze, but her demeanor is far from comforting, instead conveying a sharp, strategic intellect at work.
agent_participations.emotional_state: Livia maintains a glacial composure, masking her emotions beneath a veneer of detached pragmatism and intellectual superiority. Outwardly, she presents herself as a seasoned advisor, offering strategic counsel to Tiberius, but her tone is subtly condescending and manipulative. Internally, she is calculating and ambitious, focused on ensuring the dynasty's stability and her own enduring influence. There is a palpable tension between her role as mother and her ruthless political maneuvering, as she prioritizes the long-term power of the Julio-Claudian line above personal affections or sentimentality. She operates with cold, strategic detachment.
active_plans: Manipulate Tiberius into permitting Piso's trial, framing it as a strategic advantage for him, to manage public perception and potentially solidify her own position.
Assert her intellectual and political dominance over Tiberius, subtly reminding him of her superior insight and experience in political matters.
Control the narrative surrounding the unfolding events, ensuring that outcomes align with her long-term objectives for the dynasty, even at the expense of Tiberius's ego or immediate desires.
beliefs: She possesses unparalleled political acumen and foresight, viewing herself as the true architect of the Julio-Claudian dynasty's enduring power.
Public perception and managed appearances are paramount in maintaining power, often outweighing the importance of personal feelings or abstract notions of justice.
Ruthless pragmatism and strategic manipulation are necessary tools for survival and success in the treacherous world of Roman politics, and sentimentality is a weakness to be avoided.
goals: short-term": "Convince Tiberius to allow Piso's trial, using strategic framing to align it with his perceived self-interest.
medium-term": "Maintain and strengthen her influence over Tiberius and the Roman court, ensuring her continued role as a key power broker.

ultimate": "Secure the long-term stability and dominance of the Julio-Claudian dynasty, ensuring her legacy as the shrewd matriarch who guided its destiny through turbulent times, even if through manipulation and control.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Dim light filters into a private chamber within the imperial palace. ANTONIA, AGGRIPINA, CASTOR, VITELLIUS, CLAUDIUS, and HEROD are gathered around a table littered with strange objects.

Dialogue.Line: I can't believe it. Dearly as I loved my son, I can't believe what you're saying. Piso, yes, we all know his record. But Tiberius?
Then why did he appoint Piso Governor of Syria? There were others he could have chosen.
Well, it wasn't a good choice, I grant you. But don't ask me to believe that an Emperor of Rome would stoop to such methods.
Oh, those are his methods. He doesn't need to stoop. Yes, I'm sorry, Castor but I will say it even though he's your father.
Say it. Say it. You can say nothing against my father that I've not already said myself.
It's not for us to accuse the Emperor. We have no proof of his involvement.
Proof! The people won't need proof. The people know. They're not fools.
I've instructed the prosecutor to prepare charges against Piso and Plancina.
On wh-what grounds?
Treason and murder.
Is there really proof of murder?
And of witchery.
Is it possible? Barbarian Jew that I am, I find it incredible that the most sophisticated people on earth believe in witchery.

Oh, scoff all you like, Herod, but you judge for yourself. On our return to Syria from Egypt, Germanicus fell ill and suspected that Plancina had bribed her way into our kitchens and was having his food poisoned.
But why?

Because Germanicus had dismissed her husband, Piso. So I prepared all his food myself, but he was able to eat very little. He complained that there was a smell of death in the house, and began to believe that Plancina was using witchcraft against him. He made a propitiating sacrifice of nine black puppies to Hecate...

Dialogue.Stage Direction: laughs

Dialogue.Line: ...which was the proper thing to do when being victimized. And the very next day, a slave who was washing the floor of the hall noticed a loose tile. Lifting it up, he saw beneath it the naked and decaying corpse of a baby, its belly painted red with horns tied to its forehead. We made an immediate search of every room and equally gruesome finds were made. The corpse of a cat with rudimentary wings growing in its back. The head of a negro with a child's white hand stuck in its mouth. The skull of an ass with the word Germanicus written across it. Oh, cock's feathers smeared in blood were found among the cushions. The word Rome written upside down. And the number 17. Now, only I knew that the number 17 upset him dreadfully.
Plancina must have had accomplices at the house.
And I tell you, there could not have been. The woman dabbles in witchcraft!
Go on, Pina.

One of the things that upset him most was the appearance of his name, each day shortened by a letter. It would appear quite suddenly without explanation in rooms to which the servants had no access and where the windows were too small for a man to climb through. He told me he was doomed. But I told him no, not as long as you have the green jasper charm of Hecate with you. He felt under his pillow and he found it and that comforted him because he knew as long as he had that talisman safe, nothing could happen to him. That night, while he was asleep, he felt a tiny movement under his pillow. He turned on his side and fumbled for the charm. It was gone. Tell me, Herod, how did it disappear? Nobody but myself was allowed in that room. Who could have taken it? Who?  CALIGULA (O.S.)

Dialogue.Stage Direction: coughs

Dialogue.Line: Caligula, darling, what are you doing out of bed?
I've had a bad dream, Mother.
Oh, my poor baby. Come here. What did you dream?
Horrid dream. I dreamt there were bats sitting along the shelf in my room. Then they flew down and sat on me until I was all covered with them and no one could see me anymore.
Oh, my poor baby.
You shouldn't eat so much before you go to bed.
Oh, Mother, he's been through so much!
He stuffs himself with all manner of things.
Perhaps he'd like to sleep with Drusillus? He'd be company for him.
Would you like that darling? Would you like to sleep with your cousin's room?
I'd rather sleep with Drusilla.
Drusilla? Your sister? A boy of your age? What is the world coming to?
Oh, he doesn't mean anything by it.
He's been too long in the East. He should've been left here in Rome. Syria is no place to bring up a Roman child.
I don't like it here.
Well, you'll have to get used to it then, won't you?
What was so wonderful about the East, hmmm?
Herod Agrippa is talking to you, child!

Oh, it was full of strange and mysterious people and things. Syrians made a great fuss of him, I'm afraid. Half the time we never saw him. He wandered all over Antioch. The house slaves took him everywhere.
He had more freedom than is good for him.
Oh, I don't think so. His father was very strict with him. Now, would you like to sleep in your cousin's room as Uncle Claudius suggests?
I'll go back to my own room.
Yes, I'll take him back. Say goodnight.
Goodnight.
He's very overwrought.
Now, what about the t-t-trial?
Do you really think you can prove a charge of poisoning?
We have a witness, a woman called Martina. She's a notorious poisoner, well known in the province. She was seen many times with Plancina.
Where is she now?
On her way to R-Rome. She's being kept hidden in different places along the route.
We must find a place for her when she arrives. Sejanus' agents are out looking for her even now.
I know a place. A house of a merchant friend of mine.
Good. Now, I've applied for permission to prosecute in the courts.
Oh, I'm afraid that's n-not a good idea.
Well, it's better to have it tried in the courts than in the Senate by my father.
Your father can f-fix the courts behind the scenes. If he's tried in the Senate by him, T-T-Tiberius will be on trial too.
Oh, clever, Clau-Clau! He's right. You'll be better off in the Senate.
Then we'll move for a trial in the Senate.

metadata.title: The Council of Shadows
metadata.description: The atmosphere in the Shadowed Council Chamber is heavy with tension as dim light filters through the ornate windows, casting eerie patterns across the table laden with strange objects and relics of potential dark magic. Gathered are Antonia, Agrippina, Castor, Vitellius, Claudius, and Herod, each grappling with the implications of their grim discussion. Agrippina stands resolute, her fiery conviction stark against the skepticism of her peers. The tension escalates as accusations of witchcraft and murder are exchanged, and familial loyalties are tested. Time seems suspended as the weight of the impending trial looms over them, underscoring the fragile alliances forged in the shadow of imperial power. This scene serves as a critical turning point, revealing the depths of Agrippina's resolve and the lengths to which she will go to avenge her husband, Germanicus. It encapsulates the themes of ambition, betrayal, and the supernatural elements that permeate the political intrigue of Rome.

events.title: Antonia Questions Agrippina's Claims
events.description: Antonia expresses disbelief at Agrippina's accusations against Tiberius, questioning the Emperor's integrity. Agrippina counters fiercely, asserting that Tiberius's appointment of Piso was deliberate and malicious, igniting a heated debate over loyalty to the Emperor versus the pursuit of justice for Germanicus.
key_dialogue: I can't believe what you're saying. Piso, yes, we all know his record. But Tiberius?
Then why did he appoint Piso Governor of Syria? There were others he could have chosen.

events.title: Agrippina's Passionate Accusations
events.description: Agrippina passionately argues that the people of Rome are aware of the Emperor's true nature and do not require proof of his involvement in her husband's demise. Castor reveals he has instructed the prosecutor to prepare charges of treason and murder against Piso and Plancina, amidst rising tensions in the room.
key_dialogue: The people won't need proof. The people know. They're not fools.
I've instructed the prosecutor to prepare charges against Piso and Plancina.

events.title: The Revelation of Dark Magic
events.description: Agrippina recounts her husband's paranoia regarding witchcraft, detailing the eerie discoveries made in their home, including a decaying corpse and peculiar artifacts that suggest foul play. Her vivid narrative shocks the council, pushing the boundaries of their disbelief and setting the stage for a confrontation with the supernatural.
key_dialogue: He complained that there was a smell of death in the house, and began to believe that Plancina was using witchcraft against him.
The corpse of a cat with rudimentary wings growing in its back.

events.title: Caligula's Distraction
events.description: Caligula unexpectedly enters, disrupting the intense atmosphere with a child's fears of bats and nightmares. His innocence serves as a poignant contrast to the dark discussions surrounding him, prompting concern from his mother Agrippina and Antonia. The moment highlights the innocence lost amidst the court's treachery.
key_dialogue: I've had a bad dream, Mother.
Oh, my poor baby.

events.title: Strategizing the Trial
events.description: The council resumes their discussion about the impending trial, weighing their options about how to proceed against Piso and Plancina. Claudius raises concerns about the dangers of pursuing the case in court, emphasizing the risk posed by Tiberius's influence. The meeting concludes with plans to move the trial to the Senate.
key_dialogue: Your father can fix the courts behind the scenes.
Then we'll move for a trial in the Senate.

agent_participations.current_status: Antonia stands with her arms crossed, her posture rigid and authoritative as she listens to Agrippina's accusations. She leans slightly forward, a gesture that conveys disbelief and a need to assert her position against the claims being presented, embodying the role of a matriarch defending the integrity of the imperial family.
agent_participations.emotional_state: Antonia's surface emotion is one of skepticism, her brow furrowed and lips pursed in doubt as she challenges Agrippina. Internally, she experiences tension—a fierce loyalty to her family that clashes with the unsettling implications of Agrippina's claims. Beneath her stern facade lies a flicker of fear about the potential fallout from these accusations.
active_plans: Defend Tiberius's integrity against Agrippina's allegations.
Maintain the honor of the imperial family amidst the chaos.
Encourage her allies to remain focused on loyalty to the Emperor.
beliefs: The Emperor's authority should not be questioned without solid proof.
Family loyalty is paramount, even when faced with troubling claims.
The stability of the empire rests on the integrity of its leaders.
goals: Short-term: Quell Agrippina's dissenting voice during the meeting.
Medium-term: Ensure the loyalty of the council members remains firmly with Tiberius.
Ultimate: Protect the imperial family's reputation from the repercussions of Agrippina's anger.

agent_participations.current_status: Agrippina leans over the table, her hands gesturing emphatically as she articulates her accusations. She is animated and fierce, her body tense with passion as she confronts Antonia and the others, demanding acknowledgment of the truth she sees as self-evident.
agent_participations.emotional_state: Agrippina's surface emotions fluctuate between fury and desperation, as she confronts disbelief with fervor. Internally, she wrestles with a profound grief for Germanicus, which fuels her outrage against Tiberius. Her motivations are tangled; beneath her passionate exterior lies a painful vulnerability and an all-consuming need for justice.
active_plans: Convince the council of Tiberius's complicity in Germanicus's death.
Rally support against Piso and Plancina to ensure their prosecution.
Expose the darker forces at play in the imperial court, advocating for her husband's legacy.
beliefs: Justice for Germanicus is paramount, even if it means challenging the Emperor.
The people are not fools; they understand the truth behind the imperial facade.
Witchcraft and treachery are real threats in the machinations of the court.
goals: Short-term: Gain the support of the council in her accusations against Tiberius and Piso.
Medium-term: Ensure a legal and public reckoning for those responsible for her husband's death.
Ultimate: Restore her family's honor and secure a legacy for her sons amidst imperial chaos.

agent_participations.current_status: Agrippina stands resolute, her presence commanding the shadowed chamber. She leans forward, her gaze intense as she addresses the council, her voice ringing with conviction.  She gestures emphatically as she speaks of the people's understanding, her body language radiating a fierce determination to be heard and believed, even in the face of skepticism from some present.
agent_participations.emotional_state: Agrippina is a tempest of righteous fury barely contained beneath a veneer of aristocratic composure. Outwardly, she projects unwavering certainty and indignation, her tone sharp and accusatory as she speaks of Tiberius's 'methods'. Internally, grief for Germanicus fuels her every word, a burning ache transformed into a weapon of political assault. Beneath her pronouncements of public knowledge, there's a strategic calculation, a deliberate appeal to popular sentiment to amplify her accusations and corner her adversaries.
active_plans: To sway the council members to acknowledge Tiberius's potential involvement in Germanicus's death.
To leverage the perceived public opinion as a powerful force to legitimize her accusations and pressure Tiberius.
To ensure the legal prosecution of Piso and Plancina proceeds swiftly and decisively, ultimately leading to their condemnation and punishment.
beliefs: The Roman populace is perceptive and intuitively understands the Emperor's malevolent nature.
Circumstantial evidence and public sentiment are valid forms of 'proof' in the court of public opinion, if not necessarily in law.
Justice for Germanicus transcends legal technicalities and must be pursued with unwavering passion and conviction, regardless of imperial opposition.
goals: {type: short-term, objective: To secure immediate and vocal support from at least some council members for her accusations against Tiberius.}
{type: medium-term, objective: To incite widespread public outrage and condemnation of Tiberius, making it politically untenable for him to ignore her demands for justice.}

{type: ultimate, objective: To achieve definitive justice for Germanicus's murder, ensuring that all those responsible, including potentially Tiberius himself, are held accountable and punished, thereby vindicating Germanicus's memory and her own honor.}

agent_participations.current_status: Castor sits at the table, his posture rigid and formal as he listens to Agrippina's passionate outburst. He interjects with measured responses, maintaining a semblance of order in the escalating tension. He announces his official action of instructing the prosecutor, attempting to steer the conversation towards legal procedure and away from direct accusations against the Emperor.
agent_participations.emotional_state: Castor is visibly conflicted, caught between his duty to address Agrippina's grave accusations and his filial loyalty to Tiberius. Outwardly, he projects an air of official detachment, emphasizing process and legal channels. Internally, he grapples with the implications of Agrippina's words, his own past criticisms of his father suggesting a pre-existing unease about Tiberius's methods. He is likely anxious about the potential for public unrest and the precarious position of his family should these accusations gain traction.
active_plans: To redirect the focus from direct accusations against Tiberius to the legally actionable charges against Piso and Plancina.
To demonstrate a commitment to due process and justice to appease Agrippina and the council, while containing the damage to imperial authority.
To gather concrete evidence and prepare a legally sound case against Piso and Plancina to manage the immediate crisis and potentially defuse Agrippina's broader campaign.
beliefs: The Roman legal system, however imperfect, is the appropriate framework for addressing accusations of treason and murder.
Maintaining order and stability within the Empire is paramount, even amidst personal and political turmoil.
His duty as a Roman official requires him to investigate serious allegations, regardless of the potential implications for his own family.
goals: {type: short-term, objective: To formally initiate legal proceedings against Piso and Plancina to be seen to be taking action.}
{type: medium-term, objective: To manage and contain the fallout from Agrippina's accusations, preventing wider political destabilization and public disorder.}

{type: ultimate, objective: To uphold the appearance of Roman justice and maintain the integrity of the legal system, while navigating the complex web of familial and political loyalties without directly confronting his father, Tiberius.}

agent_participations.current_status: Agrippina stands center stage, her presence both commanding and fervent. She gestures animatedly, eyes blazing with passion as she recounts the sinister events surrounding her husband Germanicus’s death. Her posture is assertive, leaning forward, drawing her audience into the web of her revelations, a mixture of grief and righteous indignation coursing through her being.
agent_participations.emotional_state: Agrippina’s surface emotions are a tumultuous blend of sorrow and anger, her voice trembling with intensity as she recalls the dark occurrences in her home. Internally, she wrestles with a potent mix of betrayal and determination, her grief fueling a growing resolve to expose the truth. Beneath her passionate exterior, there lies an undercurrent of fear for her family's safety, as the supernatural elements she unveils risk painting her as mad in the eyes of her peers.
active_plans: To convince the council of Piso and Plancina's treachery through her vivid retelling of the events.
To rally support against Tiberius's regime, pressing for accountability in light of the evidence she presents.
To protect her children and herself from the fallout of her accusations, ensuring their safety amidst the brewing storm.
beliefs: She believes that the truth about Germanicus's demise must be revealed, regardless of the consequences.
Agrippina holds that the supernatural and witchcraft are real forces that could threaten her family, as evidenced by her experiences.
She is convinced that justice can be achieved through public outrage and the council's support.
goals: Short-term: To secure immediate attention and sympathy from the council regarding her claims.
Medium-term: To instigate a trial against Piso and Plancina, seeking justice for her husband's death.
Ultimate: To dismantle Tiberius's power and protect her family's legacy from his corrupt influence.

agent_participations.current_status: Herod remains seated at the table, his demeanor calm yet skeptical as he listens to Agrippina’s dramatic recounting. He shifts slightly, his fingers tapping lightly on the surface, indicative of his analytical mind at work. While he reacts to Agrippina’s revelations with mild disbelief, his expression remains pensive, weighing the implications of her claims against the possible repercussions.
agent_participations.emotional_state: On the surface, Herod displays a mask of rationality and skepticism, challenging Agrippina’s narrative. However, internally, he experiences a conflict between disbelief and a nagging concern about the implications of witchcraft within Roman society. His pragmatic nature propels him to question the validity of Agrippina's claims, while simultaneously recognizing the potential dangers they pose to all involved.
active_plans: To remain a voice of reason amidst the chaos, critically assessing Agrippina's claims.
To uncover the truth behind Agrippina's allegations to determine their veracity and implications.
To protect his own political position by navigating the treacherous waters of court intrigue without directly antagonizing Agrippina.
beliefs: He believes that political realities should be approached with pragmatism, rather than emotional fervor.
Herod holds skepticism towards witchcraft, seeing it as a barbaric belief that undermines the sophistication of Roman culture.
He is convinced that loyalty and reason are paramount in maintaining stability within the volatile environment of the imperial court.
goals: Short-term: To understand the full scope of Agrippina's accusations and their potential impact.
Medium-term: To position himself as a mediator who can bridge the gap between Agrippina and other council members.
Ultimate: To safeguard his own interests while ensuring that the council operates smoothly amidst rising tensions.

agent_participations.current_status: Young Caligula stumbles into the shadowed council chamber, a small figure disrupting the tense adult atmosphere. He clings to his mother, Agrippina, seeking comfort after a nightmare. He speaks with childlike vulnerability about bats and shadows, momentarily becoming the center of attention before Antonia firmly steers him back to bed, his brief presence leaving an echo of innocence in the room.
agent_participations.emotional_state: On the surface, Caligula displays fear and distress, whimpering about a 'horrid dream' and seeking his mother's embrace. Beneath this visible fear, there's a palpable need for reassurance and comfort. His vulnerability is stark against the backdrop of the adult intrigue, creating a poignant contrast that hints at the emotional fragility masked by his later infamous persona. There's also a hint of childish manipulation in seeking his mother's attention.
active_plans: To seek comfort from his mother, Agrippina, after a nightmare.
To disrupt the serious adult conversation and draw attention to himself.
To express his unhappiness with Rome and longing for the East.
beliefs: Nightmares are real and terrifying threats.
His mother is a source of unconditional comfort and safety.
Life in the East was preferable to Rome, offering more freedom and wonder.
goals: Short-term: To alleviate the fear and distress caused by his nightmare.
Medium-term: To receive affection and attention from his mother and perhaps disrupt the council's somber mood.
Ultimate: To potentially escape the unsettling environment of Rome and return to the more appealing East (though unspoken, his words suggest this longing).

agent_participations.current_status: Agrippina is initially engaged in a passionate recounting of the witchcraft accusations against Plancina, her voice filled with righteous fury. However, her demeanor instantly softens as Caligula enters. She turns her full attention to him, embracing him with maternal warmth and concern, her protective instincts overriding her previous intensity. She soothes him, attempting to alleviate his fears and reassuring him in front of the assembled council.
agent_participations.emotional_state: Agrippina’s emotional state is swiftly bifurcated. Moments before Caligula's arrival, she was consumed by vengeful anger and grief, passionately detailing the alleged witchcraft used against Germanicus. Upon seeing her son's distress, this transforms into immediate, overwhelming maternal tenderness.  Beneath the surface of her comforting words, there might be a flicker of frustration at the interruption of her urgent political mission, yet her love for Caligula clearly takes precedence, showcasing her deeply protective nature and capacity for empathy even amidst her own turmoil.
active_plans: To comfort and reassure her son, Caligula, immediately addressing his fear and distress.
To protect Caligula from any perceived negativity or criticism, including Antonia's pragmatic remarks.
To subtly deflect Antonia's criticism of Caligula's upbringing and attachment to the East.
beliefs: Her primary duty is to protect and nurture her children, especially in times of distress.
Caligula's emotional well-being is paramount and deserves immediate attention, even interrupting serious political discussions.
Antonia's traditional Roman views on child-rearing are somewhat rigid and lack understanding of Caligula's unique experiences.
goals: Short-term: To soothe Caligula's immediate fear and emotional upset.
Medium-term: To ensure Caligula feels secure and loved, reinforcing her role as his protector.

Ultimate: To raise Caligula into a strong and capable Roman, while shielding him from the harsh realities and corrupting influences of the court, though her immediate actions prioritize emotional comfort over long-term discipline in this moment.

agent_participations.current_status: Antonia is initially a composed and skeptical presence in the council, questioning the extent of Tiberius's involvement in Germanicus's death. When Caligula appears, she observes him with a practical, somewhat detached demeanor. She offers a pragmatic explanation for his nightmare – overeating – and swiftly takes charge, dismissing Agrippina's doting and firmly escorting Caligula back to bed, asserting her authority and traditional Roman values.
agent_participations.emotional_state: Antonia maintains a facade of rational composure, characteristic of her authoritative matriarchal role.  While she expresses a degree of concern for Caligula's well-being, it is tempered by her Roman pragmatism and emphasis on discipline. Beneath her outwardly practical approach, there's a hint of impatience with what she perceives as Agrippina's overindulgence of Caligula. Her emotional response is filtered through a lens of Roman stoicism and a belief in proper decorum, prioritizing order and rationality over demonstrative emotional displays.  She sees Caligula's fear as something to be managed efficiently, not necessarily deeply empathized with.
active_plans: To pragmatically assess and dismiss Caligula's nightmare as a minor issue stemming from overeating.
To reassert traditional Roman values regarding child-rearing, contrasting with what she perceives as Agrippina's excessive indulgence.
To swiftly remove Caligula from the council chamber and restore order and focus back to the serious political discussion.
beliefs: Children's distress should be addressed with practicality and firmness, not excessive emotional indulgence.
Overeating and lack of discipline are common causes of childhood disturbances like nightmares.
Roman children should be raised with a strong sense of propriety and not be overly influenced by foreign or 'Eastern' customs.
goals: Short-term: To efficiently resolve Caligula's interruption and restore order to the council meeting.
Medium-term: To reinforce traditional Roman values in Caligula's upbringing, counteracting perceived negative influences from his time in the East.

Ultimate: To maintain stability and decorum within the imperial family, ensuring future generations uphold Roman standards of behavior and governance, even if it means a somewhat detached and pragmatic approach to emotional needs.

agent_participations.current_status: Claudius sits at the table, his posture slightly hunched as he fiddles with his hands, betraying his usual nervousness. His eyes dart between the speakers, taking in the tension-filled atmosphere as he cautiously interjects with his concerns regarding the trial's implications.
agent_participations.emotional_state: Claudius exhibits a surface calmness, yet underlying anxiety thrums within him. His stutter surfaces as he expresses his worries, revealing a deep-seated fear of Tiberius’s possible retribution. He feels a compelling urge to protect the integrity of the investigation while grappling with a sense of helplessness.
active_plans: To caution the council about the risks of pursuing the trial in court due to Tiberius's influence.
To advocate for a more strategic approach to the trial that minimizes personal danger.
To gather evidence and support for the claims against Piso and Plancina without provoking Tiberius.
beliefs: Justice is essential, but it must be pursued wisely to avoid catastrophic consequences.
The power dynamics within the imperial court dictate that careful navigation is crucial for survival.
Underestimating Tiberius can lead to dire repercussions for those who oppose him.
goals: Short-term: To ensure the safety of the witnesses and key players involved in the trial.
Medium-term: To find a strategic location and method for the trial that reduces the risk of imperial backlash.
Ultimate: To secure justice for Germanicus without sacrificing his own life in the process.

agent_participations.current_status: Castor stands confidently, his hands resting firmly on the table as he speaks with conviction about prosecuting Piso and Plancina. His posture is assertive, reflecting his determination to see justice served, even in the face of familial loyalty.
agent_participations.emotional_state: Castor displays a fierce loyalty to his father while simultaneously wrestling with the weight of his convictions. There’s a blend of frustration and determination in his voice as he challenges Agrippina's criticisms, revealing an internal struggle between family duty and moral obligation.
active_plans: To escalate the legal proceedings against Piso and Plancina by preparing formal charges.
To unify the council’s support for the trial by demonstrating the urgency of the situation.
To ensure that the trial is conducted in a manner that exposes the truth and serves the public's desire for justice.
beliefs: Justice must be pursued relentlessly, even at the cost of familial ties.
The truth will ultimately prevail if enough effort is put into exposing it.
Imperial authority cannot be allowed to silence the voices of the innocent.
goals: Short-term: To gather support from his fellow council members for the trial.
Medium-term: To build a strong case against Piso and Plancina based on available evidence.
Ultimate: To restore honor to his family and demonstrate that justice can triumph over corruption.

agent_participations.current_status: Herod leans back slightly in his chair, arms crossed, observing the discussion with a blend of skepticism and curiosity. He interjects with rhetorical questions, probing the council's assumptions while maintaining a neutral demeanor throughout the intense conversation.
agent_participations.emotional_state: Herod remains outwardly composed, yet a subtle tension ripples beneath his calm exterior. He is wary of the volatile political climate and the implications of pursuing accusations against the Emperor, revealing a pragmatic approach that seeks to avoid unnecessary conflict while seeking clarity.
active_plans: To question the credibility of the accusations against Piso and Plancina to ensure the council doesn't act recklessly.
To gather more information about the evidence before forming a definitive stance on the trial.
To propose practical solutions for securing the potential witness, Martina.
beliefs: Political caution is essential in maintaining power and influence in Rome.
Accusations without solid proof can lead to dire consequences, especially against the Emperor.
Survival often requires a measured approach rather than reckless bravery.
goals: Short-term: To gain a clearer understanding of the evidence and its implications.
Medium-term: To facilitate a strategy that minimizes risks while pursuing justice.
Ultimate: To navigate the treacherous political waters without sacrificing his position or safety.
